;
;;作者 Salman Rushdie
;

;;萨尔曼·拉什迪;说过，如果只允许作者写出反映他们自己和他们自己经历的人物，“小说的艺术就不复存在了” ”。

;

;“如果我们生活在一个只有女性才能写女性、只有印度人才能写印度人、只有异性恋者才能写异性恋者的世界……那就是死亡据《泰晤士报》报道，小说家说道：“艺术。”

;
;

;;相关：;;萨尔曼·拉什迪宣布出版回忆录《Knife》，讲述 2022 年被刺伤的事情;

;
;

;在;法兰克福书展新闻发布会上讲话; 周五，这位出生于印度的英裔美国作家还表示，他在 ;哈马斯于 10 月 7 日对以色列发动袭击;。他补充说，他对以色列总理本杰明·内塔尼亚胡“可能会做出什么回报”感到“充满不祥的预感”，并希望“尽早停止敌对行动”。

;

;此次活动标志着拉什迪罕见的公开露面，他于 2022 年 8 月在纽约州的舞台上遭遇持刀袭击，幸存下来。33 年前，伊朗针对《;《撒旦诗篇》;，被认为是亵渎神明的。

;

;本月早些时候，有人宣布拉什迪关于这次袭击的回忆录，题为《刀》 ，将于 2024 年 4 月出版。在新闻发布会上被问及即将出版的书时，拉什迪表示，似乎“不可能再写任何东西了”。他还表示，这是“艰难的一年”，他“很高兴仍然留在这里”。

;

;拉什迪还在周日获得了德国图书贸易享有盛誉的和平奖，并利用这个机会致电据美联社报道，这是为了无条件捍卫言论自由。今年早些时候，25,000 欧元（21,786 英镑）奖金的德国评审团表示，他们表彰拉什迪“因为他的决心、他对生活的积极态度以及他以叙述的乐趣丰富了世界”。;德国新闻媒体 DW 采访;。 “作家能做的——以及他们正在做的——就是试图表达许多人现在所感受到的难以置信的痛苦，并让全世界关注这一点。”

;

;至少有 1,400 人遇难。本月早些时候对以色列的袭击，巴勒斯坦卫生部表示，自 10 月 7 日以来，至少有 5,087 名巴勒斯坦人在以色列对加沙的袭击中丧生。世界上最大的法兰克福书展在取消原计划的 ;庆祝巴勒斯坦作家阿达尼亚·希比利的颁奖典礼;。

;

;在周五的新闻发布会上，拉什迪还谴责了;最近起诉布克奖获奖小说家的举措Arundhati Roy;，表彰她在 2010 年发表的有关克什米尔的演讲。据法新社报道，拉什迪说：“她是印度最伟大的作家之一，也是一个非常正直和热情的人。” “认为她应该因为表达这些价值观而被带上法庭的想法是可耻的。”

; Mon, 23 Oct 2023 22:22:02 +0800 Lobby groups fought ‘hard and dirty’ against EU ban on caged farm animalshttps://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/oct/23/lobby-groups-fought-hard-and-dirty-against-eu-ban-on-caged-farm-animals
;;2023-10-23T14:00:01Z;
;
;;电池笼里的蛋鸡。
;

;《卫报》透露，肉类游说团体针对欧盟计划中的笼养母鸡和猪禁令展开了一场“艰苦而肮脏”的战争，该禁令现已被搁置。

;

;2021 年欧盟政界人士采取了激进的步骤;同意逐步淘汰;使用笼子在收到签名的请愿书后，饲养养殖动物，包括母鸡、肉鸡、猪、小牛、兔子和鹌鹑-age#:~:text=%20European%20Citizens%20Initiative%20(ECI)%20End%20the%20Cage%20Age%20was,by%20the%20end%20of%202023。">;超过一百万;人。据 ; 称，这些措施原定于 2023 年底前通过，得到了 89% 欧洲公民的支持欧盟调查;上周发布。

;

;但来自强大农业游说团体的猛烈抵制，《卫报》和;灯塔报告;，意味着该立法现在似乎被搁置。

;

;行业团体在后台指责欧盟食品安全监管机构存在偏见，一位欧盟官员表示，并推动聘请一位企业专家来重写禁令。

;

;欧洲议会环境委员会副主席安雅·哈泽坎普 (Anja Hazekamp) 表示：“工业界确实进行了艰苦的斗争，该文件脏了。他们尝试了他们能想到的一切，因为他们知道我们迫切需要动物福利立法来使我们的食品系统更加可持续和人道，这是他们最后的机会。他们不想改变，但看到改变是不可避免的，所以他们变得绝望。他们会不惜一切代价保住自己的性命。”

;

;一位了解该问题的欧盟官员告诉《卫报》，农业企业游说活动对欧盟委员会施加了“非常积极的压力”，从而“促成”了这一延误。

;

; >;

;“该行业在不同层面上都对这份文件有很强的参与度，”该官员表示。 “（他们）有一股消极情绪。政治层面上的所有劝阻论据都是由[行业]产生的一系列非常负面的信件、立场和信息逐步建立起来的。”

;

;游说者“瞄准了委员会的高层”知情人士表示，立法过程中的战略时刻“利用特权渠道”。该官员补充说，此后，高层对这项立法的态度变得“极其消极”。

;

;另一位欧盟官员表示，游说者可能一直在推动开放的大门，他表示，欧盟的农业理事会将环境和福利法视为“应该抵制的事情”。这就是董事会的心理。就像：‘Fortress Agri 必须保护自己免受所有想要改变现状的人的侵害。’”

;

;一些团体一度提交了一份长达 60 页的分析报告，认为积极的欧洲食品安全局（ Efsa）;评估;;计划中的一揽子计划;并不“公正”，并且包含“严重的科学错误”。

;

;这位官员表示：“欧洲食品安全局因科学成果而受到的这种压力总是令人不安。”

;

;这份长达 60 页的分析旨在“抹黑委员会的工作——该官员表示，特别是——并抱怨在经济和竞争力方面所做的工作缺乏透明度。

;

;根据会议纪要，游说者向欧盟官员辩称，该禁令将有效摧毁欧盟的农业部门。会议根据信息自由法发布：“如果[动物福利]标准提高得很高，欧洲的生产将会消失。”

;

;这条悲观的路线被另一条;来自强大的欧盟农场联盟 Copa-Cogeca 致委员会的信;，其中表示欧洲食品安全局的意见将“导致欧洲家禽业大部分损失” ，肉和蛋结合起来”。

;

;有一个团体“甚至提议聘请一位专家[重写]委员会的影响评估，该专家实际上是来自美国顶级[家禽]生产商的高级研究员，”第一位官员说。 “太棒了。”

;

;两名欧盟官员表示，一个新的游说团体——欧洲牲畜之声 (ELV)——非常活跃。 ELV 是一个激进型网络，采用的策略借鉴了非政府组织的策略，例如 ;快闪活动;、;Twitter 活动;和;社交媒体组织;。

;

;今年早些时候，ELV 在布鲁塞尔的主唱 Andrea Bertaglio 在美国举行的一次会议上表示观众：“至少在布鲁塞尔，我们都专注于动物福利立法的修订。”

;

;贝尔塔利奥告诉卫报，他希望避免美国式的两极分化文化战争; <他说，关于吃肉，但“当我们谈论牲畜时，我们经常谈论文化”。 “文化就我们的行为、习惯而言，就我们的方法而言，这是一个非常文化、社会学和哲学的主题。”

;

;Bertaglio，曾是一名环境记者 - 和 ;仍然自称是其中之一; - 还公开反对他所说的持续的“宣传，这种宣传将……肉类消费与气候和环境联系起来，让孩子们不断感到内疚和不安” ”。

;

;ELV 未列入欧盟透明度登记册，该组织拒绝回答有关其资金、其设立方式或其对动物福利计划的游说的问题。

; < p>;现在已经错过了欧盟动物福利立法 2023 年的最后期限，该法律;已从委员会 2024 年工作计划中删除;。已联系欧盟征求意见。

; Mon, 23 Oct 2023 22:22:02 +0800 World’s oldest known dog dies aged 31 after being saved from shallow grave as puphttps://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/oct/23/worlds-oldest-known-dog-dies-aged-31-after-being-saved-from-shallow-grave-as-pup
;;2023-10-23T13:31:17Z;
;
;;世界上最古老的狗波比的照片。
;

;当一只棕白色的狗时1992 年 5 月 11 日，一只名叫波比的小狗喵喵地来到这个世界，南斯拉夫正在分裂，洛杉矶仍在因骚乱而闷烧，《马斯特里赫特条约》的墨迹已干，莎朗·斯通在《本能》中引诱迈克尔·道格拉斯，距离《快速行动》还有五个月的时间发布自动为人民。

;

;这只已故的狗以 31 岁零 165 天的惊人年龄去世，与其说它打破了世界上最长寿狗的记录，不如说它猛烈地撼动了它。一边对一边，把它撕成碎片，埋掉，然后用一条胜利的腿（如果是年老的话）翘起它。

;

;10 月 21 日，Rafeiro do Alentejo 品种的 Bobi 在葡萄牙村庄摘下了他的凡人项圈。孔奎罗斯，他与莱昂内尔·科斯塔 (Leonel Costa) 及其家人一起度过了一生。

;

;最早的致敬之一来自吉尼斯世界纪录，该记录称这是 ;“得知世界上最年长的狗博比去世的消息，我们深感悲痛”。博比被授予;今年二月世界上最长寿的狗;，毫不费力地从;Spike the chihuahua，一只来自俄亥俄州的年轻伪装者;，相比之下，它在幼崽时就去世了，享年 23 岁零 7 天。

;

;直到博比周六去世为止，地球上有记录的最古老的犬类是;Bluey，一只澳大利亚牧牛犬; 于 1939 年去世，享年 29 岁零 5 个月。

;

;Bobi 于 1992 年在葡萄牙中部莱里亚市的兽医部门登记，并证实了他的出生日期。他的年龄也得到了葡萄牙全国兽医联盟管理的宠物数据库的验证。

;

;博比的死讯是由曾多次见过博比的兽医凯伦·贝克尔博士宣布​​的。

;

;“昨晚，这个可爱的男孩赢得了翅膀。”;她在 Facebook 上发布了;，并附上了两张看起来开朗的波比。

;

;“尽管它比历史上所有狗都活得长，但对于那些爱他的人来说，他在地球上的 11,478 天永远不够。”

;
;

;;相关：;;我永远不会忘记的宠物：格伦是一只有趣、吠叫的狗梦。然后有一天，他就不在那儿了;

;
;

;Bobi 的超长寿命（他的牲畜守护品种通常可以活 12 到 14 年），考虑到不到出生时，博比和他的三个兄弟姐妹被认为超出了需要，并注定在命运面前进入一个浅坟墓 - 与八岁的莱昂内尔·科斯塔和他的兄弟一起– 进行干预。

;

;“不幸的是，当时老年人认为将动物埋在洞里是正常的……这样它们就无法生存，”莱昂内尔·科斯塔说。

;

;当科斯塔的父母去处理小狗时，博比有幸被藏在附属建筑的一堆木头里。幸免于铲子和坟墓，他被莱昂内尔和他的兄弟收养，很快就成为了这个家庭的一员。

;

;科斯塔将博比的长寿归功于他所居住的“平静、安宁”的环境，事实上，他总是拥有这片土地，还有家里的狗的饮食。

;

;“我们吃的，他们也吃，”他说，并补充说，不过，他确实浸泡了波比的食物放在水中以去除调味料。

;

;先天和后天因素似乎都发挥了作用：波比的母亲吉拉活到了 18 岁，而科斯塔的另一只狗奇科特则活到了 22 岁。

;

; “我们认为这种情况是他们生活的正常结果，”科斯塔今年早些时候在他年长的同伴获得这一称号时说道。 “但博比是独一无二的。”

; Mon, 23 Oct 2023 21:52:01 +0800 Italian government to change rules after doctors fined for Covid overtimehttps://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/oct/23/italy-overtime-rules-fines-bari-doctors-hospital-covid-pandemic
;;2023-10-23T13:11:54Z;
;
;;一名戴着口罩、护目镜、手套和全身防护服的医护人员向穿着防护服的同事喷洒消毒剂相同的装备
;

;三名医生因在冠状病毒大流行期间工作过多而被罚款总计 37,000 欧元（32,000 英镑）后，意大利卫生部长承诺改变影响医务人员的严厉就业规定。

;

;奥拉齐奥·斯基拉奇发表此番言论之前，普利亚巴里综合医院急诊室主任维托·普罗卡奇表示，他因违反加班规则和未强制休息而被当地劳动监察局处以 27,000 欧元的罚款。他在医院的两名同事也被处以 10,000 欧元的罚款。

;

;普罗卡奇写了一封信给意大利总统塞尔吉奥·马塔雷拉 (Sergio Mattarella)，后者随后介入，暂停了处罚。

;

;他们的困境引发了一场关于意大利医疗保健系统因专业人员外流而承受的压力的争论。

;

;“昨天我们是英雄；现在我们是英雄。”今天我们是违法者，”普罗卡奇在 Facebook 上写道，并补充说，罚款“是对意大利医护人员的侮辱，也是对因大流行而经历痛苦和悲伤的公民的侮辱”。

;

;斯基拉奇表示，这些规则必须以避免再次发生员工因加班被罚款的情况。

;

;“我们已准备好提供一切支持，寻找最合适的解决方案，以便这些规定得到迅速纠正，制裁被取消这件自相矛盾的事情就结束了，”他说。 “在特殊紧急情况下，在要求并获得了自己的医生和卫生工作者的特别承诺后，国家不能对其进行制裁。”劳工部长玛丽娜·卡尔德龙 (Marina Calderone) 表示，一项检查在工会对 2021 年医务人员工作时间过长提出投诉后，巴里医院进行了检查。她补充说：“检查机构将在未来几天内进行进一步调查，以评估取消制裁的情况。” .

;

;普罗卡奇在给马塔雷拉的信中表示，他的医院在大流行期间挽救了 8,600 条生命，他对国家对待他的方式感到“沮丧和失望”。

;
;

;;相关：;;关于 Covid 的报告-19 意大利：“我们所知的生活已经停止”;

;
;

;意大利是;欧洲第一个遭受 Covid-19 大范围爆发的国家;，迫使医护人员在艰苦的条件下长时间工作。根据全国外科医生和牙医联合会 Fnomceo 的最新数据，迄今为止，已有 381 名卫生工作者死于该病毒。

;

;医务人员的处罚让人们关注已经失去的公共系统。自 2021 年以来，超过 11,000 名医务人员的工资低且压力大，促使专业人士要么提前退休，转向私营部门，要么在国外寻求更好的机会。

;

;Fnomceo 9 月初的一份报告发现，出国后，大多数人转移到了海湾国家，其中沙特阿拉伯是最“需求”的目的地，其次是阿联酋、卡塔尔和巴林。

;

;与此同时，地区卫生当局正在通过以下方式解决短缺问题：从国外招聘。 8 月，作为去年开始的一项计划的一部分，又有 120 名古巴医务人员抵达卡拉布里亚南部地区。威尼斯当局于 7 月向全科医生发出呼吁，提供诸如手术场所补贴、帮助在泻湖城市边缘提供住宿和免费停车等激励措施。

; Mon, 23 Oct 2023 21:52:01 +0800 UK officials use AI to decide on issues from benefits to marriage licenceshttps://www.theguardian.com/technology/2023/oct/23/uk-officials-use-ai-to-decide-on-issues-from-benefits-to-marriage-licences
;;2023-10-23T13:00:00Z;
;
;;显示内政部徽标转换为像素化数据的图形。
;

;政府官员正在使用人工智能根据《卫报》的一项调查，人工智能和复杂的算法可以帮助决定从谁获得福利到谁应该获得结婚证等一切事情。

;

;调查结果揭示了这种随意且常常不受控制的方式整个白厅正在使用边缘技术。

;

;至少八个白厅部门的公务员和少数警察部队正在一系列领域使用人工智能，特别是在帮助他们做出福利决策方面调查显示，移民和刑事司法。

;
;

;;相关：;;工党建议人工智能应该像药品或核能一样获得许可;

;
; < p>;《卫报》发现的证据表明，所使用的某些工具有可能产生歧视性结果，例如：

;

;;•; 工作和养老金部使用的算法(DWP)，一名议员认为该政策错误地导致数十人的福利被取消。

;

;;•; 伦敦警察厅使用的面部识别工具被发现会犯更多识别错误在某些情况下，黑人面孔多于白人面孔。

;

;;•;内政部使用的一种算法，用于标记虚假婚姻，该算法不成比例地选择某些国籍的人。

;

;人工智能通常是在大型数据集上“训练”的，然后以即使是开发工具的人有时也无法完全理解的方式分析数据。

;

;如果数据显示存在歧视的证据，专家警告说，人工智能工具也可能导致歧视性结果。

;

;Rishi Sunak ;最近热情洋溢地谈论了人工智能如何改变公共服务，“从节省教师数百个小时的课程计划时间到帮助 NHS 患者更快、更准确地获得诊断测试”。

;

;但它在公共部门的使用此前已被证明是有争议的，例如;在荷兰;，税务机关使用它来发现潜在的儿童保育福利欺诈，但在多次做出决定后被罚款 370 万欧元”即使知道这些决定。许多人担心;今年早些时候;废除了一个独立的政府顾问委员会，该委员会公共法律项目首席执行官 Shameem Ahmad 表示：“人工智能具有造福社会的巨大潜力。例如，我们可以让事情变得更有效率。但我们不能忽视严重的风险。

;

;“如果不采取紧急行动，我们可能会梦游到这样一种情况：不透明的自动化系统经常（可能是非法）以改变生活的方式使用，而人们不会这样做当这些流程出现问题时能够寻求补救。”

;

;诺森比亚大学法学教授、政府数据伦理咨询委员会前成员玛丽昂·奥斯瓦尔德 (Marion Oswald) 表示：“缺乏人工智能在公共部门使用方式的一致性和透明度。许多这些工具会影响许多人的日常生活，例如那些声称受益的人，但人们不明白为什么使用它们，也没有机会挑战它们。”

;

;苏纳克将于下周在布莱切利公园聚集各国元首参加;人工智能安全国际峰会;。唐宁街希望此次峰会能够为未来几年全球人工智能的发展制定条件，峰会将特别关注先进算法模型对全人类构成的潜在威胁。

;

;然而，多年来，公务员一直依靠不太复杂的算法工具来帮助做出有关人们日常生活的一系列决策。

;

;在某些情况下，这些工具简单且透明，例如电子护照门或车牌识别摄像头，两者都使用人工智能驱动的视觉识别软件。

;

;然而，在其他情况下，该软件更强大，并且对于受其影响的人来说不太明显。

;

;内阁办公室最近推出了;“算法透明度报告标准”;，鼓励各部门和警察当局自愿披露他们在何处使用人工智能来帮助做出可能对公众产生重大影响的决策。

;

;六个组织已根据新的透明度标准列出了项目。

;

;《卫报》检查了这些项目以及;由公法项目编制的单独数据库;。随后，《卫报》向英国每个政府部门和警察机构发出信息自由请求，以更全面地了解人工智能目前在哪些方面做出影响人们生活的决策。

;

;结果显示，至少有八个白厅各部门以这样或那样的方式使用人工智能，有些部门比其他部门使用人工智能的程度要高得多。

; ;

;NHS 在许多情况下使用了人工智能，包括在新冠大流行期间，官员们使用它来帮助识别应建议屏蔽的高危患者。< /p>;

;内政部表示，它使用人工智能在机场的电子登机口读取护照，帮助提交护照申请，并在该部门的“假婚姻分类工具”中使用，该工具标记潜在的假婚姻以供进一步调查

;

;《卫报》看到的内政部内部评估显示，该工具不成比例地标记了来自阿尔巴尼亚、希腊、罗马尼亚和保加利亚的人。

;

;与此同时，DWP 具有“综合风险”和情报服务”，它使用一种算法来帮助检测福利申请人之间的欺诈和错误。工党议员凯特·奥萨莫尔 (Kate Osamor) 认为，这种算法的使用可能突然导致数十名保加利亚人;近年来，他们的福利被暂停;，因为他们被错误地标记为提出潜在的欺诈性索赔。

;

;DWP 坚称该算法并未将国籍考虑在内帐户。一位发言人补充道：“我们正在打击那些试图利用该系统并无耻地从最需要帮助的人那里偷窃的人，同时我们明年将继续努力为纳税人节省 13 亿英镑。”

;

; DWP 和内政部都不会提供自动化流程如何运作的详细信息，但两者都表示他们使用的流程是公平的，因为最终决定是由人们做出的。然而，许多专家担心，有偏见的算法会导致有偏见的最终决定，因为官员只能审查标记给他们的案件，而且往往时间有限。

; Mon, 23 Oct 2023 21:22:01 +0800 Moon may be ‘40m years older’ than previously thought, researchers sayhttps://www.theguardian.com/science/2023/oct/23/moon-may-be-40m-years-older-than-previously-thought-researchers-say
;;2023-10-23T12:25:18Z;
;
;;1972 年阿波罗 17 号任务期间，科学家宇航员哈里森 H. 施密特在月球上。
;

;它曾照耀过恐龙，启发过最伟大的诗人，也曾被勇敢的宇航员探索过。尽管月球的存在经久不衰，但它的诞生时间仍然存在争议。现在研究人员表示他们找到了答案，揭示了地球卫星的年龄比之前认为的要早 4000 万年。

;

;科学家通过研究 1972 年阿波罗 17 号任务带回的月球尘埃中的晶体得出了这一发现。 – 宇航员最后一次踏上月球。

;

;“能够证明你手中的岩石是我们迄今为止发现的最古老的月球碎片，真是太神奇了。它是许多有关地球的问题的基点。该研究的主要作者、格拉斯哥大学的 Jennika Greer 博士说：“当你知道某个东西有多古老时，你就能更好地了解它在历史上发生过什么。”

;

;大约在形成后 1 亿年在太阳系中，当行星已经形成时，人们认为一个火星大小的天体撞击了地球，喷射出大量物质，最终形成了月球。 The energy involved in the impact meant its surface was initially molten, but as the lunar magma ocean cooled the material solidified.

;

;Crucially, it is thought the crystals scrutinised in the study formed during this cooling process, meaning their composition offers researchers the chance to probe their age, and hence the age of the moon itself.

;

;However, pinning down such timings has been tricky.; ;Some; work on lunar materials together with modelling;; ;has suggested the moon is about 4.42bn years old, but recent research into the crystals has; suggested it could be even older;.

;

;Now researchers say new analytical techniques appear to confirm that the crystals formed further back in time.

;
;

;;Related: ;;'Streets on the moon': lunar dust could be 'melted' to make solid roads;

;
;

;The approach, known as atom probe tomography, involves using a laser to evaporate atoms from crystals that have been sharpened to a very fine “nano tip”. The mass of these atoms can then be detected and the proportion of different types of uranium and lead atoms – known as isotopes – can be measured. Because uranium turns into lead over time through radioactive decay, this proportion can shed light on how old the crystals are.

;

;The upshot, ;the team write in the journal Geochemical Perspectives Letters,; is that the crystals, and hence our satellite, appear to be at least 4.46 bn years old.

;

;“This age pushes back the age of the first preserved lunar crust by ∼40 [million years] and provides a minimum formation age for the moon within 110 [million years] after the formation of the solar system,” the team write.

;

;They suggest samples of such crystals which give rise to the conclusion of a younger age could be down to the loss of lead in the material after crystallisation, skewing the resulting dating.

;

;Dr Romain Tartèse of the University of Manchester, who was not involved in the research, welcomed the study.

;

;“This indicates that the moon is at least 4.46 [billion years old], which contradicts some of the recent proposals for a young moon formation,” he said.

;

;The revelation, he added, suggests the giant impact with Earth from which the moon formed likely occurred a few tens of million years before that point.

;

;However, Tartèse noted the study assumes that the findings from the Apollo samples applies to the whole moon, which may not be the case.

;

;“This underlines the importance of returning further samples from different regions of the moon through future missions,” he said.

;

;“This study also exemplifies the great benefit of sample return missions and proper curation,” Tartèse added. “More than 50 years after these samples were returned we are still making key discovery about the moon and the inner solar system as technology continues developing.”

; Mon, 23 Oct 2023 20:52:01 +0800 Chinese surveillance firm recommits to UK after new guidancehttps://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2023/oct/23/chinese-surveillance-firm-hikvision-recommits-to-uk-after-new-guidance
;;2023-10-23T11:29:23Z;
;
;;Hikvision cameras for sale at an electronics store in Beijing
;

;Hikvision, the Chinese surveillance firm identified by the UK government as a security threat, has “recommitted” to Britain after receiving clarification that a ban on its cameras being positioned at sensitive sites does not extend to public authorities or police stations.

;

;In a message to clients, the Chinese state-owned company, whose equipment is prohibited in the US on national security grounds, said the new guidance would allow it to “move forward with our mission”.

;

;The permissive approach to Hikvision, whose cameras have reportedly been used in Uyghur “re-education camps” in the autonomous territory of Xinjiang in north-west China, has been adopted despite ministers conceding last November that the camera systems and their connectivity posed a threat to the UK's security.

;

;In a statement to the Commons last year, Oliver Dowden, now the deputy prime minister, said the government was taking “action now to prevent any security risks materialising” by ceasing deployment at “sensitive sites”.

;

;In a letter to Hikvision sent this August, the government's chief security adviser, Vincent Devine, informed the Chinese company, that while the definition of “sensitive sites” was “not public”, it applied to areas “on the central government estate where security consideration are always paramount – for example, defence and intelligence facilities”.

;

;Devine went on to reassure the Chinese company: “The policy represents instruction and advice to central government departments. It does not apply to private individuals or businesses or other public authorities (outside the central government estate) and was not intended to be relied upon by such persons in relation to their own use of visual surveillance equipment. The policy did not respond to any specific request for a 'ban' on the use of Hikvision products.”

;

;The former cabinet minister Iain Duncan Smith, who has long raised concerns about the role of the Chinese state in the UK, said the guidance provided to Hikvision was not in line with what he had been told would be government policy.

;

;He said: “It is not what I discussed with ministers at the time and not what I understood them to do be doing. If it's a security risk, it should be banned from everywhere that is a public body. And it should be well known that the government view is that the British public should not be buying Hikvision as it is a data gatherer and a security risk.

;

;“If you remember originally, Rishi Sunak was clear that they posed a systemic threat when he was standing the leadership. The Foreign Office got to him and the Treasury and they downgraded that to, ridiculously, 'an epoch-defining challenge', which is meaningless, and saying they would meet the challenge with 'robust pragmatism', which is bollocks.为什么？ Because the government has decided it can't afford to have rows with China, it wants more business. I call it Project Kowtow.”

;

;Prof Fraser Sampson, the independent biometrics and surveillance camera commissioner, who found in a survey last year that the police estate in the UK was “shot through” with Chinese surveillance equipment, told the Guardian that he did not believe Hikvision should have any involvement with the state.

;

;He said: “Trust is both imperative and an absolute. You either trust or you don't. The police need to trust their partners. If the government doesn't trust this company, why should we?”

;

;The US banned imports and sales of Hikvision equipment last year and there have been calls for the UK to follow.

;

;Beijing's national intelligence law requires firms to store their data in China and provide Chinese public security and intelligence services with access.

;
;

;;Related: ;;Britain to remove Chinese surveillance gear from government sites ;

;
;

;Justin Hollis, a public affairs director at Hikvision, said the company was not a threat to the UK's security and had ambitious plans in a range of sectors, including transport and health, having had the position clarified.

;

;He said: “Following extensive engagement, the government has written to us to acknowledge that our equipment will not be banned from the broader public sector. This decision recognises the important role Hikvision products play in protecting property and promoting public safety.

;

;“Now that we have confirmation from the UK government and the relevant legislation in the procurement bill has been debated and approved by all sides across the two houses of parliament, we are pleased to publicly renew our commitment to the UK market and move forward with our mission.”

;

;A UK government spokesperson said: “We have been consistently clear about the scope of this commitment and have recently provided an update on the definition of sensitive sites in parliament. The government is committed to publishing a timeline for the removal of surveillance equipment produced by companies subject to China's national intelligence law from sensitive central government sites.”

; Mon, 23 Oct 2023 19:52:02 +0800 Booking.com customers targeted by scam ‘confirmation’ emailshttps://www.theguardian.com/money/2023/oct/23/bookingcom-customers-targeted-by-scam-confirmation-emails
;;2023-10-23T08:00:39Z;
;
;;People eating at outdoor restaurant tables in the centre of Marseille, France
;

;Travellers using the popular hotel website Booking.com are being warned not to fall for scam emails asking them to confirm their hotel payment, after a hack of Booking.com's email system.

;

;In recent weeks the ;Observer; has been contacted by a number of customers claiming that they had received scam emails from within the Booking.com system.

;

;In each case the customer has either checked in, or was due to check in, to a hotel they had reserved using Booking.com. The email – sent from noreply@booking.com – claims their stay may have to be cancelled unless they hand over their bank card details via an embedded link.

;

;If they fail to do so within four or 12 hours – the emails vary slightly – the reservation will be cancelled. Notifications of the email have also appeared in the company's app on mobile phones.

;

;Booking.com has strenuously denied its system has been hacked and has, instead, blamed the messages on breaches in the email systems of its partner hotels.

;

;But the affected hotels are complaining that this could not have taken place at their end.

;

;;Observer; reader Julia Berridge says she was forced to cancel her bank card after she followed the instructions in the email she seemingly received from the website. She was staying in a hotel in Marseille earlier this month for two nights at a cost of €349.

;

;The email containing the fraudulent payment request – seen by the ;Observer; – had, apparently, been sent from a standard Booking.com email address. It had a link to her reservation, and came complete with all her stay details. She says the fact that a notification of the message appeared in the app on her phone made her think it was genuine.

;

;Although she didn't lose any money, she did input her card details and decided her only option was to cancel her card.

;

;Kate Wright, who works in digital commerce, was not so lucky. She had a second payment taken after responding to the same email.

;

;When she realised she had been charged twice she took it up with Booking.com, only to be told by the call centre staff that what she was saying had happened was “simply impossible”, she says.

;

;“I was made to feel like I was being hysterical – the call centre refused to believe that scammers had sent out an email using the Booking.com system. But, after two days, I eventually received a message from the hotel, again via Booking.com, saying that the system had been breached, that it knew about it, but was not telling their customers.

; ;

;“I was told to contact my bank. In the end I was refunded by the bank but only after I had spent four hours on the phone, and had my card replaced digitally. To say I am unhappy is a huge understatement,” she says.

;

;Another reader, who asked not to be named, had the same experience after booking a hotel in Cardiff. He received a similar email, he assumed, from Booking.com.

;

;“I only avoided losing hundreds of pounds because I became suspicious at the last moment before entering my card details and contacted the hotel directly.

;

;“The hotel did not seem surprised, and asked if I had received a scam email. The only way that these scammers could have this info is through a breach at Booking.com, or the partner hotel's interface, since it has all the booking details as well as previous email exchanges with the hotel in question.

;

;“This must be something that Booking.com is aware of, but is keeping quiet. Don't they have a duty to warn customers if they have been hacked?”

;

;On the Booking.com partner hub – an information site for operators using the website – hoteliers have been complaining about the problem.

;

;“Booking.com claims that someone got our login credentials, but that is not possible because we have two-factor authentication and we did not get any SMS.

;

;“So someone logged in to our account, on a new computer, but we didn't receive the SMS code nor the email 'Booking.com – new sign-in to your account,'” ;complains Hotel de Colegio.;

;

;This is the latest problem to hit the website, which fast became the go-to hotel booking site for millions of travellers. Last month it was ;accused of leaving many hotel operators and other partners across the globe thousands of pounds out of pocket ;for months on end, blaming the lack of payments on a “technical issue”.

;

;In a statement Booking.com told us that ensuring its platform was safe and trustworthy for our partners and customers was its “top priority”.

;

;“Some of our accommodation partners have, unfortunately, been targeted by very convincing and sophisticated phishing tactics, encouraging them to click on links, or download attachments outside of our system, that enable malware to load on their machines and, in some cases, led to unauthorised access to their Booking.com account,” it says.

;

;“These fraudsters then attempt to impersonate the partner to request payment from customers outside of the policy in their booking confirmation.

;

;“While neither Booking.com's backend systems, nor infrastructure, have been breached in any way, we are acutely aware of the implications of such scams by malicious third parties to our business, our accommodation partners and to our customers, who can fall victim to professional scammers.

;

;“If a customer has any concerns about a payment message, we encourage them to check the payment policy of the accommodation, which is easy to find on the property listing page, or contact our customer service team, which is available around the clock.

;

;“We will also be reaching out to the customers in these cases directly to ensure they are fully supported,” it adds.

; Mon, 23 Oct 2023 15:52:01 +0800 Venezuela: Machado takes big early lead in presidential primary votehttps://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/oct/23/venezuela-maria-corina-machado-takes-huge-early-lead-in-presidential-primary-vote
;;2023-10-23T07:36:08Z;
;
;;María Corina Machado holding a Venezuelan flag.
;

;Early returns in the Venezuelan opposition's presidential primary gave a big lead to former legislator María Corina Machado, who quickly claimed victory as the candidate to end the decade-long, crisis-ridden presidency of Nicolás Maduro.

;

;The independent National Primary Commission, which organised the primary, said about 93% of the first 601,110 ballots counted went to Machado, who entered the vote as a strong frontrunner. The rest of the votes were scattered among the other nine candidates. There was no indication of how many people had voted, and organisers were expected to release additional results throughout Monday.

;

;“Today, very powerful forces have been unleashed,” Machado told supporters gathered outside her campaign headquarters in the capital, Caracas. “Today, we have shown ourselves what we are capable of doing in the face of all the obstacles, in the face of all the abuses.”

;

;Holding Venezuela's first presidential primary since 2012 required the deeply fractured opposition to work together. Venezuelans, in turn, showed up at voting centres in and outside of their homeland, enthusiastically lining up for hours despite scorching sun and torrential rain.

;

;What they saw as a monumental exercise in democracy could still prove futile, however. While the administration agreed in principle to let the opposition choose its candidate for the 2024 presidential election, it has already barred Machado from running for office.

; ;

;Hundreds of people gathered at voting centres in neighbourhoods across Caracas even before polls opened. They stayed in line despite a rainstorm that left them soaking. They carried umbrellas, folding stools and coffee to ease the expected waits, and leaned against buildings or stood under marquees to seek shelter.

;

;Caracas resident Stephanie Aguilar, 34, cried while she waited to vote. She described the primary as the only “salvation” for her country, her daughter and son, and the millions of Venezuelans who have emigrated due to the nation's economic and political turmoil.

;

;“We want a better country, a free country, for my children ... who have grown up in this government,” Aguilar, a housewife, said as she wiped tears from her face. “They ask, 'Mom, can we go out to eat?' No, there is no money. 'Mom, can we do this thing?' No, there is no money. It is unfortunate that a society grows up under those conditions.”

;

;Jesús María Casal, the head of the National Primary Commission, blamed the hours-long delay in issuing election results on internet restrictions.

;
;

;;Related: ;;'Their last hope': can a political challenger in Venezuela pull the country out of chaos?;

;
;

;“Once we began the process of counting the results ... we detected that our server that functioned as a transmission channel was blocked, which prevents us from completing this process as scheduled,” he said.

;

;The London-based internet monitoring firm NetBlocks tweeted metrics showing “a disruption to internet connectivity in #Venezuela with high impact to Caracas”. It added that a state-owned internet service provider had claimed “an issue with its energy backup system”.

;

;David Smilde, an expert on Venezuelan politics at Tulane University, said the primary was a significant achievement for several reasons, including forcing political leaders and parties within the opposition “to reach out and speak to the people”.

;

;“And it has generated considerable enthusiasm and mobilisation in a population that has been skeptical of the opposition leadership of late,” he said.

;

;The presidential election is expected to be scheduled for the second half of 2024. Maduro is looking to extend his presidency until 2030, which would surpass the time that Hugo Chávez, his mentor, governed and established his self-described socialist policies.
